intro: Acalypha tenuiramea, commonly known as narrow-leaf jewelweed, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa and Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, opposite leaves and clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces unique, bead-like seed capsules that are often used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forests or along stream banks. Its ornamental value has led to its cultivation in some horticultural settings.

This plant thrives in humid environments and is often associated with rainforests or secondary growth habitats. It is also present in parts of the Pacific Islands, such as the Philippines and Papua New Guinea. Due to its adaptability, it can occasionally be found in disturbed or cultivated areas near its native range.
